body.p:
Blandville - Jany 30th/ 64.
Gov Bramlette
Dear Sir

this letter will be handed to you by Mrs Hudgens, a lady of estimable charater in her neighborhood. She has the misfortune to be the mother of a son now in the penitentiary for the crime of robbery. I was of counsel for Hudgens and was thrown into considerable intercourse with him I found him a young man of intelligence & learning He has evidently been well raised and his expressions of reprehension of his own crime was as vivid and I believe as genuine as a contrite heart could suggest. He I learn is

the only son of this lady and was he thereto been her stay and support. I should not request his dsicharge on this ground but persuaded as I am that if now pardoned he would sin no more I urge this as a strong persuasion.

Governor if you find your heart inclined to lean to the petition of your the mother my belief is that the future conduct of the son will justify the exercise of your kindness. I cannot say that he was not guilty but I do say that in my opinion he was operated upon by the influence of one
of the most wily rascals I have ever seen and in a moment of drunkeness went astray and was ruined
I beg to recommend Mrs Hudgens to your kind consideration and bespeak for her a gentle hearing
